title: Bivariate analysis
text:
Bivariate analysis is one of the simplest forms of <a href="Statistics">quantitative (statistical) analysis</a>. It involves the analysis of two <a href="Dependent%20and%20independent%20variables">variables</a> (often denoted as "X", "Y"), for the purpose of determining the empirical relationship between them. 
Bivariate analysis can be helpful in testing simple <a href="hypotheses">hypotheses</a> of <a href="Association%20%28statistics%29">association</a>. Bivariate analysis can help determine to what extent it becomes easier to know and predict a value for one variable (possibly a <a href="dependent%20variable">dependent variable</a>) if we know the value of the other variable (possibly the <a href="independent%20variable">independent variable</a>) (see also <a href="correlation">correlation</a> and <a href="simple%20linear%20regression">simple linear regression</a>).
Bivariate analysis can be contrasted with <a href="univariate%20analysis">univariate analysis</a> in which only one variable is analysed. Like univariate analysis, bivariate analysis can be <a href="descriptive%20statistics">descriptive</a> or <a href="inferential%20statistics">inferential</a>. It is the analysis of the relationship between the two variables. Bivariate analysis is a simple (two variable) special case of <a href="multivariate%20analysis">multivariate analysis</a> (where multiple relations between multiple variables are examined simultaneously).
When there is a dependent variable.
If the <a href="dependent%20variable">dependent variable</a>—the one whose value is determined to some extent by the other, <a href="independent%20variable">independent variable</a>— is a <a href="categorical%20variable">categorical variable</a>, such as the preferred brand of cereal, then <a href="probit">probit</a> or <a href="logit">logit</a> regression (or <a href="multinomial%20probit">multinomial probit</a> or <a href="multinomial%20logit">multinomial logit</a>) can be used. If both variables are <a href="ordinal%20data">ordinal</a>, meaning they are ranked in a sequence as first, second, etc., then a <a href="rank%20correlation">rank correlation</a> coefficient can be computed. If just the dependent variable is ordinal, <a href="ordered%20probit">ordered probit</a> or <a href="ordered%20logit">ordered logit</a> can be used. If the dependent variable is continuous—either interval level or ratio level, such as a temperature scale or an income scale—then <a href="simple%20regression">simple regression</a> can be used.
If both variables are <a href="time%20series">time series</a>, a particular type of causality known as <a href="Granger%20causality">Granger causality</a> can be tested for, and <a href="vector%20autoregression">vector autoregression</a> can be performed to examine the intertemporal linkages between the variables.
When there is not a dependent variable.
When neither variable can be regarded as dependent on the other, regression is not appropriate but some form of <a href="correlation">correlation</a> analysis may be. 
Graphical methods.
<a href="Statistical%20graphics">Graphs</a> that are appropriate for bivariate analysis depend on the type of variable. For two continuous variables, a <a href="scatterplot">scatterplot</a> is a common graph. When one variable is categorical and the other continuous, a <a href="box%20plot">box plot</a> is common and when both are categorical a <a href="mosaic%20plot">mosaic plot</a> is common. These graphs are part of <a href="descriptive%20statistics">descriptive statistics</a>.
